Everything looks good. But I think there is a misunderstanding. We are supposed to be naming things with a -puppet prefix. At least this is what we agreed to on the email list I though. See here as an example for a service that is configured via ansible:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/tree/deployment/timesync/chrony-ansible.yaml'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-12-13 01:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

To be clear I think the filename should be 	deployment/keepalived/keepalived-container-puppet.yaml'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2018-12-13 12:42:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> To be clear I think the filename should be 	deployment/keepalived/keepalived-container-puppet.yaml

well, that will create really, really long names. On an "end-user PoV", I wouldn't really see the advantage (here, I have my cap of a former sysop in charge of a running TripleO deploy).'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-12-13 13:06:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Cedric: when you flatten a tree it often means you'll end up with longer filenames to maintain the same level of recognition. Furthermore, end users (operators) typically only use Heat environment files directly, not the files we are renaming here."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-12-13 14:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-12-13 15:26:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-12-13 15:35:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-12-14 14:53:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Flatten Keepalived service configuration

This change combines the previous puppet and docker files into a single file
that performs the docker service installation and configuration.
With this patch the baremetal version of keepalived service have been removed.

Change-Id: Ic0ddf1174e1d0a62f83f26f0ca6bc29ec7b078b7
Related-Blueprint: services-yaml-flattening

commit_message:
Replace neutron-grenade job with grenade-py3

Since the grenade-py3 job is now in the neutron check and gate queues,
the neutron team would like to eliminate the neutron-grenade job as it
look like it duplicates the functionality of grenade-py3. This also
means the grenade job is now py3-compliant.

Change-Id: I9a13897754148983793edecf8a4c4fea651b024b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/622480
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/620357

commit_message:
Remove neutron-grenade job definition

Now that the grenade-py3 job is in the check and gate queues, it appears
that the neutron-grenade job is extraneous.  This removes the definition
of the job.  This is meant to be the last change to merge, after all the
ones in the other projects do.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/620356

commit_message:
Remove neutron-grenade job

Since the grenade-py3 job is now in the neutron check and gate queues,
the neutron team would like to eliminate the neutron-grenade job as it
look like it duplicates the functionality of grenade-py3.

This change depends on the substitution of grenade-py3 for
neutron-grenade in the integrated-gate project template in the
openstack-zuul-jobs repo. Since tempest includes that project template,
we inherit neutron-grenade from there as well.

Change-Id: Ib27df412aae8e399c35e92010473de09b5e617d6
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/622480
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/620357

commit_message:
Replace neutron-grenade job with grenade-py3

Since the grenade-py3 job is now in the neutron check and gate queues,
the neutron team would like to eliminate the neutron-grenade job as it
look like it duplicates the functionality of grenade-py3. This also
means the grenade job is now py3-compliant.  So we replace all instances
of neutron-grenade with grenade-py3.

Change-Id: I2fa8a50b70ee0a6137af6ed99f63d1c4e0508959
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/620357

commit_message:
Remove neutron-grenade from neutron check and gate

This change removes the neutron-grenade job from the neutron check and
gate queues.   Now that the grenade-py3 job is in the check and gate
queues, it appears that the neutron-grenade job is extraneous.

This was originally part of [1] but it was decided to split it out in
the neutron_ci meeting.  This will allow a reduced impact on CI
resources while we wait for other projects that have neutron-grenade job
in their zuul configurations to approve it's removal.

This change depends on the substitution of grenade-py3 for
neutron-grenade in the integrated-gate project template in the
openstack-zuul-jobs repo.  Since neutron includes that project
temnplate, we inherit neutron-grenade from there as well.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/620357

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/622480
Change-Id: I3c06c4f6c11e8b7b12d6cf1e509fabb529ad38f9

subject: Replace neutron-grenade job with grenade-py3
messages:
[{'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-12-04 17:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-12-04 18:02:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

do we still need to care about py2?  iirc it hasn't been depricated"}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-12-04 20:33:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> do we still need to care about py2?  iirc it hasn't been depricated

It has not been deprecated, but the wording of the "Python 3 First" community goal [1] is pretty specific: "the next phase of our adoption of python 3 is to begin running all jobs using python 3 by default, and only using python 2 to test operating under python 2 (via unit, functional, or integration tests)."

I think there are a lot of ways to shave this yak, but this accomplishes supporting python 3 for a testing type that is neither unit testing, nor functional testing, nor testing integration between components.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-12-04 20:50:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd consider it an integration test (of a specific subtype (upgrade))"}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-12-04 21:09:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I'd consider it an integration test (of a specific subtype
 > (upgrade))

OK, well it doesn't appear that the grenade repo has a grenade-py27 job or similar listed.  I would suggest you work with the OpenStack QA team to help define something that meets your needs.

If you feel strongly about it, then I can transition the definition of the job and neutron-grenade can become requirements-grenade-py27 if you wish.  You would then have ownership of it going forward."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-12-05 03:31:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> > I'd consider it an integration test (of a specific subtype
 > > (upgrade))
 > 
 > OK, well it doesn't appear that the grenade repo has a grenade-py27
 > job or similar listed.  I would suggest you work with the OpenStack
 > QA team to help define something that meets your needs.
 > 
 > If you feel strongly about it, then I can transition the definition
 > of the job and neutron-grenade can become requirements-grenade-py27
 > if you wish.  You would then have ownership of it going forward.

Yup based on my reading of[1,2] we absolutely need grenade-py2 (which is functionally the same as neutron-grenade) to exist before and use that.  I'd also posit that *not* testing that on T would be questionable with reference to [1,2]

I get that the Neutron team wants to cease maintaining this job and template and I don't want to stop that but it's also not the neutron team's role to force this migration on all the existing consuming teams.

I suggest that the Neutron team, myself and the QA team work to creating grenade-py2 in the grenade repo and transition all existing users to that, and optionally add the py3 variant.

I've started this with: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:grenade-py2  We need to do similar with neutron-grenade-multinode -> grenade-multinode-py2 and then migrate users to the new job names

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-05 03:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

i agree with matthew and tony. we need both version testing here. grenade is integration testing. We have grenade jobs of both version (py27 and py3) in integrated-gate and integrated-gate-py35 template [1]

grenade-py3 job is added recently to adopt the python-3-first goal but it did not mean to replace the existing py27 grenade job which is 

On new job for py27. neutron-grenade job is py27 job and i am not finding the value of renaming it. it has same case for all other jobs like tempest-full, tempest-*. those are py27 jobs and tempest-full-py3 are py3 jobs. 

I will suggest requirement also use integrated-gate and integrated-gate-py35 template to cover the integration testing like all other projects.

[1]
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs/tree/zuul.d/zuul-legacy-project-templates.yaml#n57

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs/tree/zuul.d/project-templates.yaml#n1391'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-12-05 04:02:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-12-14 21:55:18.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning per feedback from various people.  Thanks!'}]

commit_message:
Disable gnocchi, ceilometer, mongodb from multinode jobs

This disables the deployment of gnocchi, ceilometer and mongodb
from the multinode job until we can determine the root cause of
the failures in these charts

Change-Id: I8c936cae0b814841da12aabd6d3f95e902912bda

Hehe, +1, +1 != +2'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-13 23:08:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(8 comments)

Questions inline, so I'll wait for replies to those. I'm sure the questions I ask have already been chewed over ad nauseam and I haven't gone back over the earlier review comments. I'm giving weight to Stephen and Sean's +1s here since they definitely know a lot more about this than I do. The "let's not care about versioning" is about the biggest stickler for me, but as noted, we're not using os-vif objects across the wire yet anyway (and at this rate never will) so I can't say we should bend over backward to conform to that if it ultimately doesn't matter. If we really care about the versioned interface, we should prioritize vif negotiation using os-vif objects between nova and neutron. Otherwise we've essentially got what amounts to a fancier version of the host connector dict that nova uses with os-brick which is a random vendor-specific dict-o-doom.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-13 23:10:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

+1 since I'm generally agreeable."}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2018-12-14 11:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(8 comments)

Thanks very much for braving the review! To summarise the long journey:
1. once os-vif started using composition (with port profiles and such), ovo's versions went complex. Up till now it hasn't bitten os-vif/Nova.
2. composition over inheritance is a "cleaner model" in this case.

The way I see it, if versioning is dropped until os-vif goes over-the-wire, the object's version is effectively pinned to the os-vif library's version. It simplifies things at the cost of automation.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-12-14 15:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2018-12-14 17:50:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-14 20:41:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

FYI, Jan and I talked about this on IRC today:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2018-12-14.log.html#t2018-12-14T15:02:48

which I think gets summarized here:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2018-12-14.log.html#t2018-12-14T16:06:00-2

mriedem	jangutter: so going back to what i asked earlier http://paste.openstack.org/show/737315/ - is that correctly capturing the plan?	16:06
aspiers	mriedem: beginning to sound like we need yet another patchset then... I feel increasingly guilty each time I submit a new one ;-/	16:06
mriedem	jangutter: it doesn't need to be either extreme,	16:06
mriedem	it can be "here is the proposed high-level plan, details will be ironed out during implementation"	16:06
mriedem	but if http://paste.openstack.org/show/737315/ is the high level plan, then throw that in the spec	16:06
jangutter	mriedem: I think, the last line is probably going to be - we'll work with kuryr to help them during the transition.	16:06
mriedem	ok	16:07
mriedem	then shoot the moon i guess	16:07'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-14 20:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-14 20:44:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-14 20:44:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Jay was +2 and Jan captured my comments and the high-level transition plan is laid out nicely in here now, which was my main concern, so I'm going to approve. Thanks for your patience and diligence with this Jan."}]

commit_message:
Spec to implement os-vif generic datapath offloads

This spec details changes to os-vif to support a more generic datapath
offload model by using composition instead of inheritance.

Change-Id: I9757ffc2429de3a682d1e361ab592eb6eeca173b
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
blueprint: generic-os-vif-offloads

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-12 17:35:09.000000000', 'message': 'Remove lock on SchedulerReportClient._create_client

This is a follow up to change Idf6e548d725db0181629a451f46b6a3a5850d186
where the compute API started lazy-loading the SchedulerReportClient
because of slow startup times, presumably because of the locking
when creating SchedulerReportClient.

The lock on SchedulerReportClient._create_client is removed
since there is no clear indication that it is necessary. It was
added in change I02ac615dc26a4a0d1fd28a638f622777e41d14e4 as a
precaution:

  "I've made the _client method synchronized so that in the unlikely event
   that the resource tracker is trying to do its update job while some
   other thing is happening, we won't waste the client. This may not be
   necessary, but probably doesn't harm anything."

Long-term we could consider making SchedulerReportClient a global
singleton so a TODO is left for that since it would require inspecting
cache-sensitive methods to see if a lock is necessary.

Change-Id: I127e8b78c0dfd5c42a1e1f509dc4fca1af3d5f89
Related-Bug: #1807219
Related-Bug: #1806912
'}]
commit_message:
Remove lock on SchedulerReportClient._create_client

This is a follow up to change Idf6e548d725db0181629a451f46b6a3a5850d186
where the compute API started lazy-loading the SchedulerReportClient
because of slow startup times, presumably because of the locking
when creating SchedulerReportClient.

The lock on SchedulerReportClient._create_client is removed
since there is no clear indication that it is necessary. It was
added in change I02ac615dc26a4a0d1fd28a638f622777e41d14e4 as a
precaution:

  "I've made the _client method synchronized so that in the unlikely event
   that the resource tracker is trying to do its update job while some
   other thing is happening, we won't waste the client. This may not be
   necessary, but probably doesn't harm anything."

Long-term we could consider making SchedulerReportClient a global
singleton so a TODO is left for that since it would require inspecting
cache-sensitive methods to see if a lock is necessary.

Change-Id: I127e8b78c0dfd5c42a1e1f509dc4fca1af3d5f89
Related-Bug: #1807219
Related-Bug: #1806912

subject: Helm-toolkit: Fix hasKey call for security context snippet
messages: [{'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-14 16:34:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-12-14 18:35:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-12-14 18:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-14 16:34:22.000000000', 'message': 'Helm-toolkit: Fix hasKey call for security context snippet

This fixes the hasKey call in the pod security context snippet
template, as the call requires 2 args: a map and a key. This
addresses the problem by indexing the provided map on the
application key, before passing it to the hasKey call

Change-Id: I95264c933b51e2a8e38f63faa1e239bb3c1ebfda
'}]
commit_message:
Helm-toolkit: Fix hasKey call for security context snippet

This fixes the hasKey call in the pod security context snippet
template, as the call requires 2 args: a map and a key. This
addresses the problem by indexing the provided map on the
application key, before passing it to the hasKey call

commit_message:
get_standard_device_mappings for mechdriver

get_mappings for machanism drivers return back different dicts for
different mechanism drivers. By adding get_standard_device_mappings
method SRIOV and OVS mechanism drivers can return a mapping dict in a
form like this one:
{'physnet_name': ['device_or_bridge_1', 'device_or_bridge_2']}

Change-Id: Ieddd9b3a4f3d7269aafc373f040c55b025f5c201
Related-Bug: #1578989

os-resource-classes is a library within the nova project that provides
standard symbols for resource classes used by the placement service and
clients thereof. It is very similar to the os-traits library, on which
this file is based.

The library currently uses nova's launchpad, as it's expected to have
few bugs because it has no behaviors, just symbols.

Eventually it will be a part of the placement project, when the
separation is complete.

The release is required by placement iself, which would like to

Change-Id: I18cb98de2286a81c0ed275184b4e189f698a2d9c
"}]
commit_message:
Initial release of os-resource-classes

os-resource-classes is a library within the nova project that provides
standard symbols for resource classes used by the placement service and
clients thereof. It is very similar to the os-traits library, on which
this file is based.

The library currently uses nova's launchpad, as it's expected to have
few bugs because it has no behaviors, just symbols.

Eventually it will be a part of the placement project, when the
separation is complete.

The release is required by placement iself, which would like to
start using this library as seen in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/623556/

Change-Id: I18cb98de2286a81c0ed275184b4e189f698a2d9c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-14 06:13:58.000000000', 'message': "Fix the bug about DHCP port whose network has multiple subnets.

When a subnet's enable_dhcp attribute is updated, we must restart
dhcp device. So,when we decide whether 'restart' or
'reload_allocations' in refresh_dhcp_helper function we only compare
the cidr of subnets which enabled dhcp.

The previous logic only calls 'restart' when deleting or adding a
subnet. This may cause the dhcp port not updated when the subnet's
enable_dhcp is updated to True.

Change-Id: Ic547946ac786c5fab82b4ee7078bf86483f51eb5
Closes-Bug: #1805824
(cherry picked from commit 9aa7af82210f1ffb6274399648962b65162e17d1)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix the bug about DHCP port whose network has multiple subnets.

When a subnet's enable_dhcp attribute is updated, we must restart
dhcp device. So,when we decide whether 'restart' or
'reload_allocations' in refresh_dhcp_helper function we only compare
the cidr of subnets which enabled dhcp.

The previous logic only calls 'restart' when deleting or adding a
subnet. This may cause the dhcp port not updated when the subnet's
enable_dhcp is updated to True.

Change-Id: Ic547946ac786c5fab82b4ee7078bf86483f51eb5
Closes-Bug: #1805824
(cherry picked from commit 9aa7af82210f1ffb6274399648962b65162e17d1)

commit_message:
Fix the bug about DHCP port whose network has multiple subnets.

When a subnet's enable_dhcp attribute is updated, we must restart
dhcp device. So,when we decide whether 'restart' or
'reload_allocations' in refresh_dhcp_helper function we only compare
the cidr of subnets which enabled dhcp.

The previous logic only calls 'restart' when deleting or adding a
subnet. This may cause the dhcp port not updated when the subnet's
enable_dhcp is updated to True.

Change-Id: Ic547946ac786c5fab82b4ee7078bf86483f51eb5
Closes-Bug: #1805824
(cherry picked from commit 9aa7af82210f1ffb6274399648962b65162e17d1)

subject: Instance: show network info even if name is empty
messages: [{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-11-29 16:11:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27822, 'date': '2018-11-30 06:40:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2018-11-30 09:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nLGTM!!'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-12-14 17:51:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-12-14 17:52:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-29 16:11:19.000000000', 'message': 'instance: show network info even if name is empty

Previously, when a network name is an empty string,
network information of server interfaces will be empty,
so we cannot distinguish server interfaces.

Also network name in the instance detail page is capitalized
but there is no need to capitalize it and such information like
network name should be displayed as-is. This is not directly
related to the bug fixed by this commit, but it is simple enough
and related to network name, so I believe it is okay.

Change-Id: I2f2ad9b6bf50a2b53e79e4929d877111f875bd5b
Closes-Bug: #1805812

and related to network name, so I believe it is okay.

Change-Id: I2f2ad9b6bf50a2b53e79e4929d877111f875bd5b
Closes-Bug: #1805812
'}]
commit_message:
Instance: show network info even if name is empty

Previously, when a network name is an empty string,
network information of server interfaces will be empty,
so we cannot distinguish server interfaces.

Also network name in the instance detail page is capitalized
but there is no need to capitalize it and such information like
network name should be displayed as-is. This is not directly
related to the bug fixed by this commit, but it is simple enough
and related to network name, so I believe it is okay.

Change-Id: I2f2ad9b6bf50a2b53e79e4929d877111f875bd5b
Closes-Bug: #1805812

commit_message:
Ensure kubelet pod has default connectivity with Network Policies

This patch set ensures kubelet pod has default connectivity when
Network Policies are using the namespace subnet driver

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
 
Change-Id: Icb3144dc90b80e1ae828fd8777866f64fdb7ff6f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-15 13:48:13.000000000', 'message': 'Increment versioning with pbr instruction

With moving away from required milestone releases, the version numbers
calculated by PBR on the master branch will not work for those testing
upgrades from the last stable release. More details can be found in the
mailing list post here:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135706.html

This is an empty commit that will cause PBR to increment its calculated
version to get around this.

PBR will see the following which will cause it to increment the version:

Sem-Ver: feature

Please merge this patch as soon as possible to support those testing
upgrades.

Change-Id: I93dea617ce3f4388aa4269aa5eb0541a41029807
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Increment versioning with pbr instruction

With moving away from required milestone releases, the version numbers
calculated by PBR on the master branch will not work for those testing
upgrades from the last stable release. More details can be found in the
mailing list post here:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135706.html

This is an empty commit that will cause PBR to increment its calculated
version to get around this.

PBR will see the following which will cause it to increment the version:

Sem-Ver: feature

Please merge this patch as soon as possible to support those testing
upgrades.

Change-Id: I93dea617ce3f4388aa4269aa5eb0541a41029807
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Ensure network policies are not applied on pod with host networking

This ensures kuryr-controller is not trying to add security
groups to the pods with host networking as those are not mananged
by kuryr cni

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: Ie43a6783675c6870e2f93ac6902cfdcdd500caa4

commit_message:
Add support for podSelector

This include support for both types, when pod selector is used alone
or together with a namespace selector.

TODO in follow up patch sets:
- React to new pods/namespaces created with labels
- React to pod/namespaces relabeling/deletion

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: Ie29b9da64fcd5df7b9a0e9af7b4835208f76da66

commit_message:
add python 3.6 unit test job

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.6 as part of the python3-first goal.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I72d4101d9edb049b58f5ce662160f9629dbf1665
Story: #2002586

> to terse sorry, what happens if we use the same journal block dev

it will create the partitions on same disk for each osd ( partition size is 10gb by default)

example journal disk: 

sdb      8:16   0   446G  0 disk
├─sdb1   8:17   0    10G  0 part
├─sdb2   8:18   0    10G  0 part
├─sdb3   8:19   0    10G  0 part
├─sdb4   8:20   0    10G  0 part
├─sdb5   8:21   0    10G  0 part
└─sdb6   8:22   0    10G  0 part'}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2018-12-12 18:44:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> (1 comment)

no it wont as i have tested with below config: 

 storage:
    osd:
      - data:
          type: block-logical
          location: /dev/sdc
        journal:
          type: directory
          location: /var/lib/openstack-helm/ceph/osd/osd-sdc
      - data:
          type: block-logical
          location: /dev/sdd
        journal:
          type: directory
          location: /var/lib/openstack-helm/ceph/osd/osd-sdd'}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2018-12-12 19:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2018-12-12 19:39:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

LGTM, this PS contains minimal changes to the ceph-osd chart code that allows ceph-disk to create partitions from a journal disk (provided the whole disk is used, otherwise we fall back to previous behavior). In addition the daemon is now ran without specifying the journal disk as a command arguement. The reasoning for this change is that Ceph stores metadata about the journal inside of the OSD already.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-12-14 16:59:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22713, 'date': '2018-12-14 17:07:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Ceph: Journal partition automation

- Use whole disk /dev/sdc format.
- Don't specify partition and let ceph-osd util create
and manage partition.
- On an OSD disk failure, during manintanance window,
Journal partition for failed OSD should be deleted.
This will allow ceph-osd util to reuse space for new partition.
- Disk partition count num will continue to
increase as more OSD fails.

Change-Id: I87522db8cabebe8cb103481cdb65fc52f2ce2b07

'}, {'created': '2018-10-23 12:22:55.000000000', 'message': 'Fix doc build error

Doc build keeps failing w/

Recursion error:
    maximum recursion depth exceeded while pickling an object

commit_message:
Fix doc build error

Doc build keeps failing w/

Recursion error:
    maximum recursion depth exceeded while pickling an object

Sphinx recommends bumping up the recursion limit to
get around this, and it appears to work.

Change-Id: If0a78f9af2e4ddd5fd88c44757642355b3a5bf2e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-05 16:53:52.000000000', 'message': 'SF: Handle qos values on extend volume

For the Solidfire cinder driver when volume extend is called on a volume
that has a qos with scaledIOPs=True, the values scaleMin, scaleMax,
scaleBurst are ignored, thus when a volume grows the iops values stay
the same when they should either grow or shrink.

To correct the bug _retrieve_qos_setting has a new argument size with a
default value of zero. This allows all previous calls to function
properly, and saved duplicating code.

Extend volume now calls _retrive_qos_settings with the new size argument
and then includes that qos with the call to solidfire api  ModifyVolume.

Closes-Bug: #1782588
Change-Id: I8cb7b1eccbc63ef4077e86324afdd1a11409343d
'}]
commit_message:
SF: Handle qos values on extend volume

For the Solidfire cinder driver when volume extend is called on a volume
that has a qos with scaledIOPs=True, the values scaleMin, scaleMax,
scaleBurst are ignored, thus when a volume grows the iops values stay
the same when they should either grow or shrink.

To correct the bug _retrieve_qos_setting has a new argument size with a
default value of zero. This allows all previous calls to function
properly, and saved duplicating code.

Extend volume now calls _retrive_qos_settings with the new size argument
and then includes that qos with the call to solidfire api  ModifyVolume.

Closes-Bug: #1782588
Change-Id: I8cb7b1eccbc63ef4077e86324afdd1a11409343d

[{'created': '2018-03-28 18:29:01.000000000', 'message': 'Ironic Inspector - disjoint ip range(s) for HA

Allow tht parameter IronicInspectorSubnets to specify
per-instance ip range(s) using hostname as key for each
list of ip ranges. For HA deployments use disjoint
address pools to avoid potential address conflict.

commit_message:
Ironic Inspector - disjoint ip range(s) for HA

Allow tht parameter IronicInspectorSubnets to specify
per-instance ip range(s) using hostname as key for each
list of ip ranges. For HA deployments use disjoint
address pools to avoid potential address conflict.

Implements: blueprint ironic-inspector-overcloud
Depends-On: Ifae513265b8c35d98012f14f951bac33ae90b66c
Change-Id: Ifdebe9fcc817b4572f1eb461a3396af6b55f1e6b

commit_message:
Add traffic control exceptions

Added new traffic control exceptions TcLibQdiscNeededArguments
and TcLibQdiscTypeError in ``neutron-lib.exceptions.qos``.

Related-Bug: #1560963

Change-Id: I4cad9bbfc5e0ed20bd24be33544ba0fa06898f54

commit_message:
Migrate n-g-s jobs to Zuulv3

Sets up jobs for Zuulv3, and marks the python3 jobs as n-g-s's
use of tooz seems to be incompatible with python3.

Change-Id: Ic3f4980125a2be8e63a3596c28979b8df015afd5

commit_message:
openstackclient 0.1.0

The openstackclient deliverable was never released (or published
to Pypi) while its documentation advises to use pip install.

This initial release fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I062f89d7111ac4329e3659483c917aa30bd47e91

commit_message:
Clarify release management for murano deliverables

After discussion with Murano's PTL, murano-apps is an
example repository (not meant to be released) and
murano-deployment is deprecated.

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 7700, 'name': 'Nikolay Mahotkin', 'email': 'nikolay.makhotkin@gmail.com', 'username': 'nmakhotkin'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 8731, 'name': 'Renat Akhmerov', 'email': 'renat.akhmerov@gmail.com', 'username': 'rakhmerov'}, {'_account_id': 9712, 'name': 'Dougal Matthews', 'email': 'dougal.matthews@canonical.com', 'username': 'dougal'}, {'_account_id': 18955, 'name': 'dharmendra', 'email': 'dharmendra.kushwaha@gmail.com', 'username': 'dharmendra'}, {'_account_id': 21970, 'name': 'Andras Kovi', 'email': 'akovi@nokia.com', 'username': 'andras.kovi'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

[{'account_id': 25553, 'date': '2018-10-18 06:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25553, 'date': '2018-10-18 10:17:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-10-18 10:38:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2018-11-02 05:29:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-05 15:50:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

I'll fix the nits in the docs."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-05 15:51:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-05 15:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-11-07 02:04:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

test failure is fixed in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614211/'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-11-07 02:04:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-11-19 06:54:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I have my doubts about the usefulness of this tool in general. A generic tool can check for very basic config options only. It should be made very clear that this script does not give guarantees, just checks for known issues.
Also, it should be clarified how this tool can be used. If someone has an installation that has not been updated to the latest patch release, it is very much possible that they don't have the newest checker tool either. Maybe an independently installable utility could be a better approach.
I see that this is a cross-project effort but I think it is important to see that, to my understanding, Mistral is practically more often used as standalone installed service than embedded in cloud deployments."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-05 22:51:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think I've asked this before, elsewhere, but I can't find it now, but I wasn't sure if mistral would be a good fit for this upgrade check utility if mistral does not hold state (like horizon) or otherwise have moving parts for upgrades beyond deprecation of config options and such. I don't really know enough about mistral.

There is a lot more documentation on how upgrade checks are used within nova to try and provide examples of how they could be useful to other services:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/upgrade-checks.html

I think at some point, that documentation will be made more generic and moved into the oslo.upgradecheck library docs."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-14 16:34:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Here is an example deprecation note from queens:

https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/mistral/queens.html#deprecation-notes

"The YAQL/jinja2 expression function json_pp has been deprecated and will be removed in the S cycle. json_dump should be used instead."

When removing that deprecated functionality, if it's possible to determine that it is being used and would break on upgrade, then an upgrade check could be added for that. How that is used depends on how  to determine if you can check for it on upgrade though. I don't know enough about the internals of mistral to say, i.e. if there is something in the database that says it's using that deprecated function, that would be a pretty easy way to find out I would think.'}]

commit_message:
Add framework for mistral-status upgrade check

This commit adds the functionality of mistral-status CLI for performing
upgrade checks as part of the Stein cycle upgrade-checkers goal.
It only includes a sample check which must be replaced by real checks in
future.

Change-Id: Idabba09caeb3757bee30e688227e0e2736191574
Story: 2003657
Task: 26141

subject: Combine, rather than replace init overrides
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-14 14:33:07.000000000', 'message': 'Combine, rather than replace init overrides

In I48a303d12e749e6d27a7f57c6f2dd93a98d16f9c the init override
used the update function, effectively replacing all contents of
cinder_environment_overrides which was not the intention. This
patch correctly applies the combine filter to merge the contents
instead, resulting in the cinder-volume service correctly able
to find the appropriate binary for cinder-rtstool in the path.

Change-Id: Ib4a432ec4437e9c75ee28eedd9a9fec30cf1b9a5
'}]
commit_message:
Combine, rather than replace init overrides

In I48a303d12e749e6d27a7f57c6f2dd93a98d16f9c the init override
used the update function, effectively replacing all contents of
cinder_environment_overrides which was not the intention. This
patch correctly applies the combine filter to merge the contents
instead, resulting in the cinder-volume service correctly able
to find the appropriate binary for cinder-rtstool in the path.

Change-Id: Ib4a432ec4437e9c75ee28eedd9a9fec30cf1b9a5

commit_message:
report whether delegated reviewer has commented on patch

Sometimes the delegate comments without voting, and that is useful to
have when trying to decide if a patch is ready for approval.

Change-Id: I9001cbe8c8a47f4a2185b0c49a5b4aa931c6fa1a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Update charter to include PTL appointment

We've had a couple projects go through changes in leadership, for
which we do have a couple formalities, but they weren't written down.
This commit updates the charter to include the items that need to be
taken care of if a PTL steps down and appoints another individual to
the role.

Change-Id: Ie162d3c66abc698bf31e7224530869a836e111e9

messages: [{'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2018-06-26 18:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-06-26 20:43:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-06-26 21:06:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-06-26 21:51:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 19307, 'date': '2018-12-14 15:45:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/ocata as commit 3f42bdec3e992834d5ee3b897fd30cfa52c91eb7'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-26 18:20:54.000000000', 'message': "Dropping radvd process privileges

radvd needs to run as root, but has the capability to drop privileges on
linux hosts. Currently, radvd process is not using this feature and
this can be considered a serious risk.

In addition, some distributions like SUSE, radvd process runs as a non
privileged user by default, causing radvd failure to daemonize
because it can't write the pid in the corresponding neutron folder and
break the IPv6 functionality.

This patch allows radvd process to run with the same user used by
neutron. In order to allow this, it changes the radvd config file
permissions to 444 because radvd doesn't allow that this file can be
writeable by self/group. The readonly mode is not a problem updating the
file because of the way the neutron_lib replace_file function handles
the files operations.

Closes-Bug: #1777922

Change-Id: Ic5d976ba71a966a537d1f31888f82997a7ccb0de
Signed-off-by: aojeagarcia <aojeagarcia@suse.com>
(cherry picked from commit 9f2b40f2cecc116906e77d69797c0c6877bd5b4d)
"}]
commit_message:
Dropping radvd process privileges

radvd needs to run as root, but has the capability to drop privileges on
linux hosts. Currently, radvd process is not using this feature and
this can be considered a serious risk.

In addition, some distributions like SUSE, radvd process runs as a non
privileged user by default, causing radvd failure to daemonize
because it can't write the pid in the corresponding neutron folder and
break the IPv6 functionality.

This patch allows radvd process to run with the same user used by
neutron. In order to allow this, it changes the radvd config file
permissions to 444 because radvd doesn't allow that this file can be
writeable by self/group. The readonly mode is not a problem updating the
file because of the way the neutron_lib replace_file function handles
the files operations.

Closes-Bug: #1777922

Change-Id: Ic5d976ba71a966a537d1f31888f82997a7ccb0de
Signed-off-by: aojeagarcia <aojeagarcia@suse.com>
(cherry picked from commit 9f2b40f2cecc116906e77d69797c0c6877bd5b4d)

commit_message:
Add DownCellFixture

This adds a new testing fixture which allows controlling
when nova.context.scatter_gather_cells returns exception
results for down cells. This will be useful in functional
tests for the down-cell support API microversion to show
the API returning minimal construct results for resources
in down cells like instances and services.

Part of blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: Iabc1e55550e8d9d82e20facfaf84316892c5564a

commit_message:
Remove tripleo newton and ocata jobs (rocky branch)

Non-containerized multinode scenario jobs are no longer supported
and should be removed from zuul config.

Change-Id: I0c98aecd82478fbf7e2b2a45d5b2664290155ed9

commit_message:
Remove slow tests from blacklist

c6d3b84 intended to turn on
"TestEncryptedCinderVolumes.test_encrypted_cinder_volumes_luks",
but it didn't since that test is marked as slow.

It only turned on
"TestVolumeBootPattern.test_boot_server_from_encrypted_volume_luks".

Change-Id: Ifa8ec1651be95dd6d8d30ed5d04e9ac692209e50

commit_message:
Fix the ironic_inspector config file in the switch-vlans validation

The 'puppet-generated' sub-directory was missing in the ironic_inspector
configuration file path.

Change-Id: I13b0a46a936d58614f0ed3a1c66d96a4b1c539b7
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-10 06:42:13.000000000', 'message': 'Although previous XClarity driver passes the unit test, we find that
getting boot order function test fails in the 3rd party CI, which will
throw an exception of "Unsupported boot device". After checking with
the code, we find that a boot device mapping from XClarity to Ironic
recoginzed format is needed.

This patch will fix this getting boot order defect. We have verified
this function in our 3rd CI environment. Also it will fix a minor
in power.py.

Change-Id: Ia7ccf986cb6b1c332691c811d32cb41850d4796c
Story: 2004576
Task: 28351

in power.py.

'}, {'created': '2018-12-10 17:24:22.000000000', 'message': 'Fix XClarity driver management defect

Although previous XClarity driver passes the unit test, we find that
getting boot order function test fails in the 3rd party CI, which will
throw an exception of "Unsupported boot device". After checking with
the code, we find that a boot device mapping from XClarity to Ironic

commit_message:
Fix XClarity driver management defect

Although previous XClarity driver passes the unit test, we find that
getting boot order function test fails in the 3rd party CI, which will
throw an exception of "Unsupported boot device". After checking with
the code, we find that a boot device mapping from XClarity to Ironic
recoginzed format is needed.

This patch will fix this getting boot order defect. We have verified
this function in our 3rd CI environment. Also it will fix a minor
in power.py and enhance the unit test.

Change-Id: Ia7ccf986cb6b1c332691c811d32cb41850d4796c
Story: 2004576
Task: 28351

commit_message:
Allow for service_bootstrap_ips empty list in IpListMap

It seems in some cases we get an empty list for services in
service_bootstrap_ips and the yaql expression fails. Though
there can be better solution to not look for EnabledServices
for roles that has zero count, this would probably fix the
immediate scenario008 failures.

Change-Id: Ife1fc3f7736ed5743c80fa3748a75cb0bb52b817
Closes-Bug: #1808240

commit_message:
Undercloud Validations - Deprecated (replaced/removed) opts

Add a validation method to check for invalid (replaced/removed)
configuration options. Fail the validations if any such options
are detected in the configuration.

After the deprecation period is over and options are removed we
can add options to 'invalid_opts' to make sure users update
their configuration.

Closes-Bug: #1794038
Depends-On: Ia29a3aaeb23e63d68cfe4891436446093016ea3c
Change-Id: I26a1626aac9178ed87176b6577fcca970dfc182b

commit_message:
Put user data in the main stack

We create user data per instance, but two are global for all, and the
last one per role, so we can move it up the stack.

Change-Id: I1330e54744adef9be159edd8f01aefa3db85a480

Change-Id: I7537a459d33de215b007a558ba27c10d7c361185

commit_message:
Cleanup test-requirements

python-subunit is not used directly anywhere
and it is dependency of both testrepository
and os-testr
(probably was used by some tox wrapper script before)

Change-Id: I7537a459d33de215b007a558ba27c10d7c361185

subject: Restrict bashate to devstack/lib instead of lib
messages: [{'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-12-14 11:40:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-14 12:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-12-14 12:30:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-14 11:40:32.000000000', 'message': 'Restrict bashate to devstack/lib instead of lib

`lib` is too general in *nix systems and CI can clone the project to
directories that contain it (like `/var/lib/`) which leads to bashate
running on files it should not run (like `devstack/settings`) and fail.

Change-Id: Ia618b10a1c1c483f58bb4380af77c24e7fc2f01c
'}]
commit_message:
Restrict bashate to devstack/lib instead of lib

`lib` is too general in *nix systems and CI can clone the project to
directories that contain it (like `/var/lib/`) which leads to bashate
running on files it should not run (like `devstack/settings`) and fail.

Change-Id: Ia618b10a1c1c483f58bb4380af77c24e7fc2f01c

1) --use-heat can be used in Rocky to force a deployment or an upgrade
of a non containerized undercloud, even if we don't support it.
2) the option is removed in Stein.

Change-Id: I89f0d4ef0578b0cef569492ba4445b723d586547
"}]
commit_message:
undercloud: add a note about --use-heat option.

1) --use-heat can be used in Rocky to force a deployment or an upgrade
of a non containerized undercloud, even if we don't support it.
2) the option is removed in Stein.

Change-Id: I89f0d4ef0578b0cef569492ba4445b723d586547

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-23 21:09:25.000000000', 'message': "Convert policy.json into policy-in-code

This commit introduces a framework for policy-in-code support
in the neutron stadium and converts the existing policy.json
in the neutron repository into the policy-in-code style.

Policy-in-code support in neutron stadium is a bit different from
other projects because the neutron server needs to load policies
in code from multiple projects. Each stadium project should register
the following two entry points: named oslo.policy.policies and
neutron.policies in setup.cfg.

oslo.policy.policies =
    neutron = neutron.conf.policies:list_rules
neutron.policies =
    neutron = neutron.conf.policies:list_rules

The above two entries are same, but they have different purposes.

* The first entry point is a normal entry point defined by oslo.policy
  and it is used to generate a sample policy file [1].
* The second one is specific to the neutron stadium. It is used by
  neutron.policy module to load policies of stadium related projects.

oslo.policy.policies entry point is used by all projects which adopt
oslo.policy, so we cannot determine which projects are neutron stadium
projects, so the second entry point is required.

The recommended entry point name is a repository name:
For example, 'neutron-fwaas' for FWaaS and 'networking-sfc' for SFC.

Except registering 'neutron.policies' entry point, other steps to be
done in each stadium project for policy-in-code are same for all
OpenStack projects.

NOTES:
1) This commit tries not to change the existing policy behavior
provided by the neutron repository even if there are some stale policies
or policies to be defined in a neutron-related project.

"}, {'created': '2018-09-12 07:01:38.000000000', 'message': "Convert policy.json into policy-in-code

This commit introduces a framework for policy-in-code support
in the neutron stadium and converts the existing policy.json
in the neutron repository into the policy-in-code style.

Policy-in-code support in neutron stadium is a bit different from
other projects because the neutron server needs to load policies
in code from multiple projects. Each stadium project should register
the following two entry points: named oslo.policy.policies and
neutron.policies in setup.cfg.

oslo.policy.policies =
    neutron = neutron.conf.policies:list_rules
neutron.policies =
    neutron = neutron.conf.policies:list_rules

The above two entries are same, but they have different purposes.

* The first entry point is a normal entry point defined by oslo.policy
  and it is used to generate a sample policy file [1].
* The second one is specific to the neutron stadium. It is used by
  neutron.policy module to load policies of stadium related projects.

oslo.policy.policies entry point is used by all projects which adopt
oslo.policy, so we cannot determine which projects are neutron stadium
projects, so the second entry point is required.

The recommended entry point name is a repository name:
For example, 'neutron-fwaas' for FWaaS and 'networking-sfc' for SFC.

Except registering 'neutron.policies' entry point, other steps to be
done in each stadium project for policy-in-code are same for all
OpenStack projects.

NOTES:
1) This commit tries not to change the existing policy behavior
provided by the neutron repository even if there are some stale policies
or policies to be defined in a neutron-related project.
They should be clean up later in Stein release.

2) 'default' policy should be dropped from the default policies
as all default policies should be defined in the code (as many projects
which already completed policy-in-code do). However, dropping 'default'
policy potentially affects policy behavior in neutron-related projects,
so it needs to be visit carefully. Considering this, this commit decides
to keep the 'default' policy.

Change-Id: I6a61079da4d4f5080ee32d640144e6bdb14735fa

commit_message:
Convert policy.json into policy-in-code

This commit introduces a framework for policy-in-code support
in the neutron stadium and converts the existing policy.json
in the neutron repository into the policy-in-code style.

NOTES:
1) This commit tries not to change the existing policy behavior
provided by the neutron repository even if there are some stale policies
or policies to be defined in a neutron-related project.
They should be clean up later in Stein release.

2) 'default' policy should be dropped from the default policies
as all default policies should be defined in the code (as many projects
which already completed policy-in-code do). However, dropping 'default'
policy potentially affects policy behavior in neutron-related projects,
so it needs to be visit carefully. Considering this, this commit decides
to keep the 'default' policy.

Partially Implements: blueprint neutron-policy-in-code
Change-Id: I6a61079da4d4f5080ee32d640144e6bdb14735fa

[{'created': '2018-11-29 07:56:05.000000000', 'message': 'Bump storage available to Docker in CI to 25G

Currently CentOS binary jobs are often failing due to running out of
storage while building images.

See
http://logs.openstack.org/87/612887/8/check/kolla-build-centos-binary/b467920/logs/build/000_FAILED_heat-all.txt.gz
for an example, and
http://logs.openstack.org/87/612887/8/check/kolla-build-centos-binary/b467920/logs/df.txt.gz
for the corresponding df output that shows the /var/lib/docker loopback
mount at 97%.

Change-Id: I2f3d04452c517f8643b124550148cc9d8320b937
(cherry picked from commit 3d4f69f57920f87d12d00414ea0c980d0a958f97)
'}]
commit_message:
Bump storage available to Docker in CI to 25G

Currently CentOS binary jobs are often failing due to running out of
storage while building images.

See
http://logs.openstack.org/87/612887/8/check/kolla-build-centos-binary/b467920/logs/build/000_FAILED_heat-all.txt.gz
for an example, and
http://logs.openstack.org/87/612887/8/check/kolla-build-centos-binary/b467920/logs/df.txt.gz
for the corresponding df output that shows the /var/lib/docker loopback
mount at 97%.

Change-Id: I2f3d04452c517f8643b124550148cc9d8320b937
(cherry picked from commit 3d4f69f57920f87d12d00414ea0c980d0a958f97)

commit_message:
Mark mysql related functional tests as unstable

Thos tests are failing quite often because of timeouts. Details
are in related bug report.
Lets make our life easier and mark them as unstable until we will
figure out how to fix this issue.

Change-Id: I47743e519c41795bba64e4da041a87bffd947fbd
Related-Bug: #1687027

Code looks good for me but as it is change of existing API behavior it should be discoverable so You should add some shim API extension for that.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2018-10-24 08:52:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> Code looks good for me but as it is change of existing API behavior
 > it should be discoverable so You should add some shim API extension
 > for that.

Thanks for reviewing this, and I need some advice:
1. Currently, the limitation here will be enforced anyway. And such behavior should not change since neutron L3 do not need such IP change. So if add a shim API extension, do I need to check the extension here to decide whether enable the IP change restriction here? Or do not check it, just left it as it is now.
2. Is there any information/guide/doc about shim extension? About what scenario/when should add a shim extension?
IMO, as I just said in 1., neutron L3 will not allow such IP change action directly and permanently, so I think a release note can be a simple way to notify user that such behavior should not happen anymore.
3. If we add a shim extension, this patch seems not be able to backport to stable branch. Or maybe backporting this is not acceptable, since you consider this has some API behavior.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2018-10-24 10:00:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2018-10-24 11:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/608909/12 : SUCCESS in 1h 39m 34s'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-10-24 13:28:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> > Code looks good for me but as it is change of existing API
 > behavior
 > > it should be discoverable so You should add some shim API
 > extension
 > > for that.
 > 
 > Thanks for reviewing this, and I need some advice:
 > 1. Currently, the limitation here will be enforced anyway. And such
 > behavior should not change since neutron L3 do not need such IP
 > change. So if add a shim API extension, do I need to check the
 > extension here to decide whether enable the IP change restriction
 > here? Or do not check it, just left it as it is now.

You should check if Your extension is enabled and only then forbid to update some of IP addresses

 > 2. Is there any information/guide/doc about shim extension? About
 > what scenario/when should add a shim extension?

I don't know about any guide like that.

 > IMO, as I just said in 1., neutron L3 will not allow such IP change
 > action directly and permanently, so I think a release note can be a
 > simple way to notify user that such behavior should not happen
 > anymore.

IMO we should add such extension but maybe I'm wrong. Lets check what others will say about that.

 > 3. If we add a shim extension, this patch seems not be able to
 > backport to stable branch. Or maybe backporting this is not
 > acceptable, since you consider this has some API behavior.

As I said, IMO it shouldn't be backportable as it changes existing API behavior and user can see it."}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-10-24 21:36:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-09 10:36:57.000000000', 'message': 'Forbiden some port type change IP address

Some L3 ports can now be directly modify the IP address,
but there are some type of device_owner, for instance
network:router_centralized_snat, should not allow to change
the IP address, otherwise it will make things really complicated.

Change-Id: I2890a71abc82cb781b601afb879bdcca10e39257
Closes-Bug: #1796824
'}, {'created': '2018-10-09 16:49:28.000000000', 'message': 'Forbiden some port type change IP address

'}, {'created': '2018-10-10 11:00:51.000000000', 'message': 'Forbiden some port type change IP address

Some L3 ports can now directly modify the IP address,
but there are some types of device_owner, for instance

Remove one unit test case since it will not occur in

Change-Id: I2890a71abc82cb781b601afb879bdcca10e39257
Closes-Bug: #1796824
'}, {'created': '2018-10-14 08:37:57.000000000', 'message': 'Forbiden some L3 related port type change IP address

Some L3 ports can directly modify the IP address now,
but there are some types of device_owner, for instance
network:router_centralized_snat, should not allow to
change the IP address, otherwise it will increase L3
agent code complexity.

Since router public gateway port is related to the
external network, and this port can be used for some
service, like VPN. So after this patch we will only
allow the gateway port to update the IP address
directly, aka device_owner network:router_gateway.

The following l3 router ports will not allow directly
port IP address updating:
  network:ha_router_replicated_interface
  network:router_centralized_snat
  network:router_ha_interface
  network:router_interface

'}, {'created': '2018-10-15 01:57:20.000000000', 'message': 'Forbiden some L3 related port type change IP address

Some L3 ports can directly modify the IP address now,
but there are some types of device_owner, for instance
network:router_centralized_snat, should not allow to
change the IP address, otherwise it will increase L3
agent code complexity.

Since router public gateway port is related to the
external network, and this port can be used for some
service, like VPN. So after this patch we will only
allow the gateway port to update the IP address
directly, aka device_owner network:router_gateway.

The following l3 router ports will not allow directly
port IP address updating:
  network:ha_router_replicated_interface
  network:router_centralized_snat
  network:router_ha_interface
  network:router_interface
  network:router_interface_distributed

Remove one unit test case since it will not occur in
neutron.

Change-Id: I2890a71abc82cb781b601afb879bdcca10e39257
Closes-Bug: #1796824

commit_message:
Prevent some L3 ports change IP address

Some L3 ports can directly modify the IP address now,
but there are some types of device_owner, for instance
network:router_centralized_snat, should not allow to
change the IP address, otherwise it will increase L3
agent code complexity.

Since router public gateway port is related to the
external network, and this port can be used for some
service, like VPN. So after this patch we will only
allow the gateway port to update the IP address
directly, aka device_owner network:router_gateway.

The following l3 router ports will not be allowed to
directly update the IP address:
  network:ha_router_replicated_interface
  network:router_centralized_snat
  network:router_ha_interface
  network:router_interface
  network:router_interface_distributed

Remove one unit test case since it will not occur in
neutron.

Change-Id: I2890a71abc82cb781b601afb879bdcca10e39257
Closes-Bug: #1796824

commit_message:
Add updates to standalone containers prep

Standalone job was not running updates at containers, so we were not
using latest versions of package or even stuff from gating repo. this
patch add this to the generated default parameters.

Change-Id: Ia83944a54ab6b0410e4e4e48dbef6602a17724be
Closes-Bug: #1805968

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-14 03:10:45.000000000', 'message': 'Set region_id for karbor_client

region_id has a default value hardcoded in Karbor code equal to
"RegionOne" which could be an issue if a different region is define.

Change-Id: Ia13496156515d0f871e8fa9bd3584940a32759e9
Closes-Bug: #1798125
(cherry picked from commit 4bb5b3354736b0c253b645eb1482c36e4f34aa00)
'}]
commit_message:
Set region_id for karbor_client

region_id has a default value hardcoded in Karbor code equal to
"RegionOne" which could be an issue if a different region is define.

commit_message:
Fix Karbor endpoints

From Karbor documentation, endpoints should be created with
"%(project_id)s" and not with "%(tenant_id)s".

This is very important because of this commit in Karbor which is
looking for a string "project_id".

Change-Id: I8fc640891d0d58541198cc8f2e942d8db6e8d02f
Closes-Bug: #1805705
(cherry picked from commit 22284676f6cc3f6cca96819ce41434bedba83887)

commit_message:
Removing barbican and telemetry from skiplist

Barbican and telemetry is being executed on scenario002, we should test it.
The launchpad bug for telemetry is marked as fixed. Barbican doesn't
have a launchpad bug so, removing to check if it will work, if so, keep
it, if not, add a lp bug

Change-Id: Ibd4e37f63bba91d22e3be58c9f2d954c035f607b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-10 22:53:38.000000000', 'message': 'Increase Galera self-signed SSL CA expiration

Currently we generate the CA certificate with default expiration time (30
days), while both CSR and signed certificates are set to expire in 3650 days.
If a Galera service is restarted after 30 days, replication breaks due to
expired CA certificate.

Increasing the CA certificate expiration to 3650 days resolves the issue and
makes expiration consistent between the certificates.

Change-Id: Ibf5ca5c0504b681b8c6d8c3aae44b2039bd47ece
'}]
commit_message:
Increase Galera self-signed SSL CA expiration

Currently we generate the CA certificate with default expiration time (30
days), while both CSR and signed certificates are set to expire in 3650 days.
If a Galera service is restarted after 30 days, replication breaks due to
expired CA certificate.

Increasing the CA certificate expiration to 3650 days resolves the issue and
makes expiration consistent between the certificates.

Change-Id: Ibf5ca5c0504b681b8c6d8c3aae44b2039bd47ece

This change looks good to me, Deepak. If you could remove the deployment scripts for shaker from the ./tools/deployment/developer/foo directories, this should be okay to bring in (as shaker is a bit heavy handed for openstack infra)'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-11-20 17:49:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

(1 comment)

thanks Steve, I understand that shaker is heavy to run in OSH/Infra gates, thats why I already removed it from the gate scripts. Though script is kept in ./tools/deployment/developer/.. but it is not invoked from any gate scripts. A lot of core logic on how to invoke the charts is in this script. It shall be helpful for a person trying to deploy shaker charts. So if we can keep it there then it wud be helpful as a reference to deploy the chart'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-11-26 20:27:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 38.'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-11-26 20:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 39.'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-11-26 20:33:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-11-30 18:19:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-11-30 19:47:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-12-01 03:23:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-12-01 05:54:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-12-02 23:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-03 13:54:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-12-04 04:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-12-04 14:20:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-04 16:56:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 40: Patch Set 39 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-04 16:57:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41: Patch Set 40 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-12-04 17:53:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 41:

i thought were we going to target this for 'addons?"}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-12-04 18:50:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 41:

@Chris, yes because we wanted to verify the shaker charts in gates. But we found out that addons doesn't create an Openstack environment against which shaker can execute its tests. So there is no point adding the chart in addons if verification can't happen. So in that case its better to keep the chart in OSH and remove it from deployment gates scripts"}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-07 15:09:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41: Workflow-1

This has been moved to osh-addons instead.  Could we go ahead and abandon this change?'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-07 15:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-07 15:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-12-07 15:10:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 41: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:35:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Moved to openstack-helm-addons: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615624/'}]

subject: Add domain level limit support
messages:
[{'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-09-04 03:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-09-04 06:23:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-09-04 06:37:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-09-19 09:18:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm not clear why this doesn't already work if we give the domain ID as the project ID? Is it just an implementation detail that prevents us from treating the domain as a project?"}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-09-20 06:38:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

> I'm not clear why this doesn't already work if we give the domain
 > ID as the project ID? Is it just an implementation detail that
 > prevents us from treating the domain as a project?

because meanwhile, we don't use domain as project for unified limit. For example, if project_id is domain_id, keystone will rasie error:
https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/limit/core.py#L60
and in strict-two-level model, we don't treat domain as one level, should domain level be considered?

So I think this spec would main focus on that once we allow domain level limit, what will be impacted. Like:
1. Should the API be changed (Like I mention in the spec)
2. how to count hierarchical layer?
3. about backward capability, how to make sure the domain level limit will not break the existing project limit.

I'll add more content about why and how later."}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-09-27 08:12:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-08 18:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-08 18:44:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Just a couple major concerns so far, mostly around the hierarchy depth including domains.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-10-11 01:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Hi wangxiyuan. Some inline comments. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-10-31 07:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-10-31 07:31:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-11-27 10:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11022, 'date': '2018-11-29 00:51:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Good start, however I think you need to cover some error cases as well, for example:
- What happens if I try to have the sum of limits of the projects bigger than the domain limit?'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-11-29 15:37:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

I'd be fine if this merged, but I agree with Lance and Rodrigo's suggestions as well. Can give my +2 back if you decide to do another revision."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-11-29 22:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Good start, however I think you need to cover some error cases as
 > well, for example:
 > - What happens if I try to have the sum of limits of the projects
 > bigger than the domain limit?

Most of those details are already addressed here: 

http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/rocky/strict-two-level-enforcement-model.html#enforcement-diagrams'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-11-29 22:59:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-11-30 02:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-11-30 02:24:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

Also added a error handler part to address Rodrigo and Colleen's comment.

@Lance, Thanks for the link"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-11-30 14:35:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11022, 'date': '2018-11-30 19:25:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

LGTM, let's wait for @Lance's take, though."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-12-03 21:37:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

Looks good. Thanks for the updates.

I'd like to give some other reviewers a little time to make sure this all makes sense before merging it."}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-12-04 02:54:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:18:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.
Update to reflect reality, which should help with local running of
constraints targets.

commit_message:
Ingress: Share container PID namespaces under docker

This PS shares pid namespaces for containers in pods under docker,
bringing running in this runtime inline with other runc based container
backends, allowing the pause process in the pod to act as a reaper.

Change-Id: I70965a62b585de31fb953ba98189a84021dba1cb
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

commit_message:
Consolidate service catalog docs

Part of the "manage services" document was redundant with the "service
catalog" document. This change combines the two, additionally adding a
note about how to create an endpoint once a service is created.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-02 15:23:11.000000000', 'message': 'Sharing hypervisor /var/lib/ironic with ironic-conductor container

While puppet-config generation, ironic-conductor will call ironic::pxe
to copy files and create directories required for tftpboot and httpboot
to /varlib/ironic on container.

But /var/lib/ironic of hypervisor is not being shared with ironic-conductor,
the changes that were done on container are not present on hypervisor.

For ironic-inspector the previously generated configs are required to move
forward and apply its own puppet-configs.

In order to make the configs generated by ironic-conductor available to
ironic-inspector, hypervisor /var/lib/ironic must be shared with
ironic-conductor container as well while generating puppet-config.

Change-Id: I5ee1a78ea7b7681e0dc1387fc5af598919ecb397
Closes-Bug: 1795776
(cherry picked from commit 6b7f1384219a8dd37468f0ff7c8edbc729df4ff4)
'}]
commit_message:
Sharing hypervisor /var/lib/ironic with ironic-conductor container

While puppet-config generation, ironic-conductor will call ironic::pxe
to copy files and create directories required for tftpboot and httpboot
to /varlib/ironic on container.

But /var/lib/ironic of hypervisor is not being shared with ironic-conductor,
the changes that were done on container are not present on hypervisor.

For ironic-inspector the previously generated configs are required to move
forward and apply its own puppet-configs.

In order to make the configs generated by ironic-conductor available to
ironic-inspector, hypervisor /var/lib/ironic must be shared with
ironic-conductor container as well while generating puppet-config.

Change-Id: I5ee1a78ea7b7681e0dc1387fc5af598919ecb397
Closes-Bug: 1795776
(cherry picked from commit 6b7f1384219a8dd37468f0ff7c8edbc729df4ff4)

[{'created': '2018-10-31 10:16:43.000000000', 'message': "Generate Ceph configuration during upgrade

If upgrading the nova, cinder or manila services via 'kolla-ansible
upgrade', the Ceph config files are not generated. Users will expect
that these files are generated, to pull in any changes from their
configuration or the base kolla configuration.

This change moves Ceph tasks inside config.yml to ensure that they are
performed during deploy, reconfigure and upgrade. This has been done for
nova, cinder, gnocchi and manila - glance already does this.

Change-Id: Ic75692c2bcba9b81dee922ff6fbbccd160e7fa19
Closes-Bug: #1794275
(cherry picked from commit 242625dff438d90b44943a94575f6601a12570d7)
"}]
commit_message:
Generate Ceph configuration during upgrade

If upgrading the nova, cinder or manila services via 'kolla-ansible
upgrade', the Ceph config files are not generated. Users will expect
that these files are generated, to pull in any changes from their
configuration or the base kolla configuration.

This change moves Ceph tasks inside config.yml to ensure that they are
performed during deploy, reconfigure and upgrade. This has been done for
nova, cinder, gnocchi and manila - glance already does this.

Change-Id: Ic75692c2bcba9b81dee922ff6fbbccd160e7fa19
Closes-Bug: #1794275
(cherry picked from commit 242625dff438d90b44943a94575f6601a12570d7)

[{'created': '2018-12-12 16:48:18.000000000', 'message': 'Use Ubuntu Xenial distro for integration tests

Default Ubuntu release which is used under devstack, has been changed
from Xenial to Bionic [1].
Fortunately, backward compatibility for Xenial was added.

Until we are not compatible with Bionic, we need to use older
Ubuntu distro.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/610977/

Change-Id: I66c63cf4fa6e5ac201a0fef1d4a8d26520b3b803
Signed-off-by: Marcin Piwowarczyk <m.piwowarczy@samsung.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use Ubuntu Xenial distro for integration tests

Default Ubuntu release which is used under devstack, has been changed
from Xenial to Bionic [1].
Fortunately, backward compatibility for Xenial was added.

Until we are not compatible with Bionic, we need to use older
Ubuntu distro.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/610977/

Change-Id: I66c63cf4fa6e5ac201a0fef1d4a8d26520b3b803
Signed-off-by: Marcin Piwowarczyk <m.piwowarczy@samsung.com>

commit_message:
functional: retrieve cluster to get stack_id

At the moment, if a cluster fails to be created, we fall back to
getting the node information from Heat directly.  However, this
behaviour doesn't work at the moment because `self.cluster` is
a copy of the API record on-create which does not have the stack
ID yet.

This patch makes an extra HTTP request to get the `stack_id` in
order to get the server IPs and be able to pull down the correct
information.

Story: #2002589
Task: #28341
Change-Id: I3fb3542f8ab63f38a23094d579d3df1fcb99a497
(cherry picked from commit d6cc77b16f329cf69f1428b3cd540f88959df149)

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I15eb789db64c58865fc3dae99a7e83f90c971a60
Closes-Bug:  #1801657

commit_message:
Split trusts docs between admin and user guide

Trusts are user-facing, so explaining how they work should be in the
user guide. Cleaning up expired trusts is still an administrative task,
so leave that in the admin guide.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-29 06:29:57.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for s390x arch in kolla

s390x is a well known arch that used by enterprises
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux_on_z_Systems

on s390x there are following hypervisors:
z/VM: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z/VM
KVM: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel-based_Virtual_Machine

both of them are now supported by nova:
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/support-matrix.html

The patch set is going to enable kolla (later on other deploy tools
such as kolla-ansible) on s390x arch for *KVM on s390x*.

This patch adds s390x into common arch definition.

Change-Id: I8f943b0ed186fd688120309b45900db5c1677d0b
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for s390x arch in kolla

s390x is a well known arch that used by enterprises
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux_on_z_Systems

on s390x there are following hypervisors:
z/VM: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z/VM
KVM: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel-based_Virtual_Machine

both of them are now supported by nova:
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/support-matrix.html

The patch set is going to enable kolla (later on other deploy tools
such as kolla-ansible) on s390x arch for *KVM on s390x*.

This patch adds s390x into common arch definition.

Change-Id: I8f943b0ed186fd688120309b45900db5c1677d0b

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I4631177d8bc714e8ed4e27d6fab662a99fe6b96c

commit_message:
Fix fluentd input log parser for OpenDaylight

OpenDaylight logs have different format than openstack,
is a karaf log with java error traces.
This PS add required config to make fluentd parse properly
ODL logs.

Change-Id: I34fb96c8a424679b3b618f2ff6a840b8dc165bec
(cherry picked from commit 76482c9a681f71a6c3a2cef35e8235536333979e)

commit_message:
Add 'Review-Priority' for Cinder repos

Following the work done for Designate with
Id7b4c6b219899fa7ed86554257264af7efe20408, this adds a Review-Priority
label for Cinder to allow easier priority dashboard creation and a
cleaner way to do procedural blocking during freezes.

Change-Id: I491ff9293eadebb10f36ed75fc8fc5ae12f92139
